The Elder Dhotaka’s Birth Story
The Ganges River is called the Bhāgīrathī,
it flows from the Himalayas;
Through the gate of Haṁsavatī,
it flows on.
The monastery called Sobhita,
was well-built on the bank of the Ganges;
There the Buddha Padumuttara,
the leader of the world, stayed.
Like the moon surrounded by the stars,
he was honored by humans;
The Fortunate One sat there,
like a fearless lion.
In the city of Haṁsavatī,
I was a brahmin;
My name was Chaḷaṅga,
that was the name of the great sage.
Eighteen hundred disciples,
surrounded me at that time;
Together with those disciples,
I went to the bank of the Ganges.
There I saw the ascetics,🔽who had removed deceit and washed away evil;
As they were crossing the Bhāgīrathī,

Padumuttara, the knower of the world,

‘The one who had a bridge built for me,
with faith in his own hands,
I will praise him,
listen to me as I speak:

translated: The benefits of giving a bridge🔽Whether falling from a mountain,
or from a tree,
or falling from a precipice,
this is the result of giving a bridge.
With a root and a lineage that has grown,
like a banyan tree by a creeper;
Enemies do not prevail,
this is the fruit of the bridge-giving.
Thieves do not prevail,
nor do Nobles despise him;
All enemies will be crossed over,
this is the fruit of the bridge-giving.
One who is peaceful, living in the open air,
heated by the hard sun;
Connected with meritorious deeds,
there will be no suffering.
In the deva world or among humans,
well-made elephant vehicles;
By the mere thought of it,
they will appear right then.
With a thousand, swift as the wind,
Sindhu horses, fast vehicles;
They will come in the morning,
this is the fruit of the bridge-giving.
Having come to the human state,
this one will be happy;
Like a human in the sky,
there will be elephant vehicles.
In a hundred thousand aeons,
born in the family of the crows;
By the name of Gotama,
a teacher will appear in the world.
A heir to his Dhamma,
emblem of the Dhamma on his chest;
Having fully understood all the pollutants,
will be extinguished, without pollutants.’
Oh, what a good deed I did,
in the most excellent lake, Anotatta;
Having made merit there,
I attained the destruction of the pollutants.
I am intent on striving,
calm, without attachment;
Like an elephant who has broken the bonds,
I live without pollutants.
My defilements are burned up,
I live without pollutants.
Welcome indeed it was for me,
I have done the Buddha’s bidding.
The four analytical insights,
I have done the Buddha’s bidding.”🔽Thus the elder monk Dhotaka recited these verses.
